name: Printing Press
description: Mechanical device using movable type for applying pressure to an inked surface, transferring ink to paper, revolutionizing communication.

name: Oil Painting
description: Painting technique using pigments mixed with a drying oil as a binder, allowing for greater depth, blending, and realism.

name: Color Printing (Woodblock, Intaglio)
description: Early techniques for producing images with multiple colors using carved woodblocks or engraved metal plates.

name: Scientific Method
description: Systematic observation, measurement, experiment, and the formulation, testing, and modification of hypotheses.

name: Humanism
description: Intellectual movement emphasizing human potential and achievements, drawing on classical antiquity.

name: Banking
description: Sophisticated financial institutions and practices, including lending, currency exchange, and investment, often family-run.

name: Double-Entry Bookkeeping
description: Accounting system that records each transaction in at least two different accounts, providing a clearer financial picture.

name: Joint-Stock Companies
description: A business entity in which shares of the company's stock can be bought and sold by shareholders, pooling capital for large ventures.

name: Early Stock Exchanges
description: Formal marketplaces for buying and selling shares of companies and commodities.

name: Mercantilism Economic Theory
description: Economic nationalism aiming to build a wealthy and powerful state by maximizing exports and accumulating precious metals.

name: Astronomy
description: Study of celestial objects and phenomena, revolutionized by new tools, mathematical models, and the scientific method.

name: Clockwork Mechanisms
description: Precision gears and escapements enabling mechanical clocks and automata.

name: Scientific Instrument Making Guilds
description: Specialized craft guilds focused on the design and construction of precision instruments for science and navigation.

name: Telescope
description: Optical instrument that magnifies distant objects, revolutionizing astronomy.

name: Planetary Motion (Kepler's Laws)
description: Mathematical description of the motion of planets in elliptical orbits around the Sun, challenging geocentric models.

name: Cartography
description: Creation of detailed and accurate maps for exploration, trade, and governance, enhanced by the printing press.

name: Cartography (Mercator Projection)
description: Development of new map projections, like Mercator's, aiding navigation for global exploration by representing lines of constant course as straight segments.

name: Surveying Theodolite (Early Precision)
description: Development of more precise surveying instruments incorporating telescopic sights and graduated circles.

name: Pocket Watch
description: Portable timekeeping devices made possible by advancements in clockwork mechanisms and miniaturization.

name: Microscope
description: Instrument for viewing very small objects, opening up the microscopic world.

name: Microbiology (Early Observations)
description: Initial observations of microorganisms ('animalcules') using early microscopes, revealing a previously unseen world.

name: Human Anatomy & Physiology
description: Detailed study of the structure and function of the human body through systematic dissection and observation.

name: Anatomical Studies (Vesalius, Detailed)
description: Revolutionary anatomical atlases based on direct human dissection, correcting ancient errors and illustrated with high-quality prints.

name: Blood Circulation (Harvey)
description: Discovery and demonstration of the systemic circulation of blood, pumped by the heart in a closed loop.

name: Global Exploration
description: Voyages of discovery leading to increased knowledge of world geography, cultures, and resources, driven by trade and empire.

name: Botanical Gardens & Systematic Collection
description: Establishment of gardens for the scientific study and classification of plants, often linked to universities and fueled by global exploration.

name: Perspective in Art
description: Artistic techniques for creating an illusion of three-dimensional depth on a two-dimensional surface.

name: Linear Perspective (Vanishing Point)
description: A mathematical system for representing three-dimensional objects and space on a two-dimensional surface using vanishing points.

name: Early Firearms
description: Development of personal gunpowder weapons like arquebuses and muskets, initially cumbersome matchlock designs.

name: Muskets (Flintlock)
description: Advancement in firearm technology with the flintlock mechanism, improving reliability and ease of use.

name: Musketry Formations
description: Military tactics developed for ranks of soldiers armed with muskets, such as volley fire.

name: Naval Artillery (Broadside Cannons)
description: Mounting cannons along the sides of warships for powerful broadsides, transforming naval warfare.

name: Logarithms & Early Calculus
description: Development of mathematical tools like logarithms for computation and foundational concepts of calculus (fluxions, infinitesimals).

name: Scientific Societies
description: Formation of organizations (e.g., Royal Society) to promote scientific inquiry, share knowledge, and publish findings.

name: Political Philosophy (Machiavelli)
description: A shift in political thought towards realism and pragmatism, analyzing power as it is, rather than as it should be.

name: Encyclopedic Compendiums & Knowledge Organization
description: Systematic collection and organization of knowledge in comprehensive printed works.
